Now to a story about the power of local politics.
While LGBTQ people say they face discrimination in many areas of life, nearly two-thirds of those surveyed in a new report say local government represents their views somewhat or very well.
That's according to a new poll by NPR, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the Harvard T.H.
Chan School of Public Health.
Will Stone of member station KJZZ has this report from Phoenix.
More than a decade of advocacy in Arizona schools began for Laurie Provost in a coffee shop when she spotted an intriguing blue lunchbox with the letters GLSEN.
I'm like, what is that?
I really want to know more about it.
She started telling me all about GLSEN.
As in the Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network.
Maddie Adelman was the one carrying the lunchbox.
She had recently founded the Phoenix chapter of the advocacy group after moving here in the late '90s to teach at the university.
It was hard to find my people.
And there weren't a lot of people talking about LGBT issues at the time.
Over the course of their friendship, they've watched the culture shift in their city.
And they've been a part of it, says Adelman - serving on city boards or advocating for policies like Phoenix's non-discrimination ordinance.
Where we're going to see the most change is local level, so I'm dedicating my time to working with individual schools, individual districts, individual cities and seeing if we can knit them together.
Adelman and Provost say Arizona is behind on LGBTQ rights.
It lacks statewide employment protections and even prohibits schools from, quote, ""portraying homosexuality as a positive alternative lifestyle.
I feel like I'm constantly looking for - looking up, what's the latest bill that they're writing or trying to pass?
Or what are we going to have to combat?
Who am I going to have to call?
But Arizona's two biggest cities, Phoenix and Tucson, are different.
For example, Adelman points out both get perfect scores for inclusivity from the Human Rights Campaign.
The city of Phoenix has been a leader, and that's because the people in the city have appropriately demanded that they do so.
Well, the local level is the gateway for equality.
Neil Giuliano knows firsthand.
He served as Republican mayor of the city of Tempe during the mid-'90s and came out while in office.
He took pro-LGBTQ stances that angered some of his constituents, even leading to a recall vote which he survived.
It was very divisive for the community.
From an emotional standpoint, we went through that and came out much stronger and much better on the other end.
Giuliano went on to lead national advocacy groups and says progress comes from the bottom-up - ordinances, appointing people to boards.
LGBT people, especially on a local level, have been much more fully integrated into the life of their community and so their neighbors and their friends, people at church.
That's how Daniel Hernandez waded into politics by running for his school board at age 21.
And over time, he says his constituents - some Catholic and socially conservative - became more receptive.
I mean, it didn't matter that I was openly gay, but what mattered was the work that I was doing to represent and the relationships that I had built.
David, thank you so much.
And that gave him room to make reforms in school policy like protections for gender identity.
It's a different political reality for Hernandez now.
He serves in the Republican-dominated Arizona legislature and recently helped launch the state's first LGBTQ caucus.
There is a point where the stuff happening at the local level reaches a nexus where it has to have an impact statewide.
Like when state lawmakers passed a religious freedom bill three years ago.
After a huge backlash, the governor vetoed it.
But fellow LGBTQ caucus member Tony Navarrete acknowledges turning local momentum into statewide change may be slow going.
Whether we get it passed this next coming session or whether we get it passed two years from now, we are developing a roadmap of how we are going to make sure that Arizona's more inclusive.
And, Navarrete says, the fact that a roadmap's beginning to take shape, no matter how winding, is progress.
For NPR News, I'm Will Stone in Phoenix.
